section.title: Introduction
section.para: This guide helps new users begin working with SciDB. There is also a complete manual, the 250-page SciDB User's Guide, available.
There are three basic ways that you can get started:

listitem.para: Download a VirtualBox image.
Use the SciDB Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to create your own AMI.
Download and install a full version of SciDB from the forum. SciDB and the User Guide can both be downloaded using the following link: http://www.scidb.org/forum/viewforum.php?f=14.

note.para: Note: Both the VirtualBox and AMI SciDB installations are small-scale—they are both single-instance installations. That is, they are useful as an introduction to SciDB, and for small amounts of data. If you want to use SciDB on very large datasets, we recommend that you download the full version of SciDB from the forum.

section.para: If you have any questions or concerns, contact support@scidb.org for help getting started.

section.title: Use the SciDB VirtualBox Image
section.para: We have created a VirtualBox image that contains SciDB 13.2. Consult https://www.virtualbox.org/ for more information about VirtualBox.

note.para: Note: The VirtualBox VM was created on VirtualBox 4.1.12, and also tested on VirtualBox 4.2.

step.para: Download the image provided by Paradigm4 at the following URL:
Download the .ova file to a partition with at least 8GB of available space.
Open VirtualBox and click File | Import Appliance and select the downloaded file.

Start the VirtualBox image.
Note: When you attempt to start the image, you may get an error similar to the following:
Failed to open a session for the virtual machine SciDB13.2-CentOS6.3-VirtualBox4.1.12.
If you receive this error, click Settings and then OK. You should now be able to start the image.
Log in using the following credentials:username: scidb password: paradigm4
The supplied database is mydb. Start SciDB by typing the following command:scidb.py startall mydb

section.para: You are now ready to walk through the remaining steps in this guide: proceed to .

section.title: Use an Amazon Machine Image
section.para: We have created an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) that contains a saved Virtual Machine with SciDB installed. You can use Amazon's EC2 service to instantly launch this machine, log into it and use SciDB. It requires an Amazon Web Services account and Amazon will charge you a small hourly fee for using their EC2 service. Consult http://aws.amazon.com/ for more information.
To work with the SciDB 13.2 AMI, perform the following steps:

step.para: Create the AMI image.
If you do not already have an Amazon AWS account, create one at http://aws.amazon.com/.
On the Amazon Web Services page, select My Account/Console > AWS Management Console.
Click EC2.
Click Instances, then Launch Instance.
Select Classic Wizard and click Continue.
Select Community AMIs and enter ami-24f8604d (the name of the SciDB image) into the text field. This should return the details for the ami-24f8604d image.
Click Select. The remaining steps of the Wizard apply to starting any instance on AWS. Note the following parameters:

listitem.para: Security Groups: For your security group, create a rule permitting incoming TCP SSH connections on port 22.

Key Pairs: If desired, you may create a Key Pair or use an existing one. This will allow logging into the instance as the ubuntu or root users using PKI rather than a password. Alternatively, you can log into the instance as the scidb user using the default password paradigm4.

step.para: Launch and log onto the image.
On the final page of the wizard, click Launch. This launches your instance.
On your AWS console page, your instances are listed.
Wait a few minutes for the image to come fully online. When you see running in the State column, click the Instance.
Note that this is an example: your public DNS will be different.

Open a terminal window from your computer to SSH into the AMI as the scidb user.ssh scidb@ec2-54-242-36-232.compute-1.amazonaws.comAgain, the URL is an example only. When asked for the scidb password, enter paradigm4.
The supplied database is mydb. Start SciDB by typing the following command:scidb.py startall mydb

section.para: You are now ready to walk through the remainder of this guide.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: The following terms are useful when learning about SciDB.

listitem.para: SciDB uses multidimensional arrays as its basic storage and processing unit. An array has any number of dimensions and attributes (see below). A user creates a SciDB array by specifying dimensions and attributes of the array.
Dimensions form the coordinate system. An n-dimensional SciDB array has dimensions d1, d2, ..., dn. The size of the dimension is the number of ordered values in that dimension.

Each combination of dimension values identifies a cell or element of an array, which can hold multiple data values called attributes (a1, a2, ..., am). Each data value is referred to as an attribute, and belongs to one of the supported data types in SciDB.

AFL is a functional language for working with SciDB arrays. AFL operators are used to compose queries or statements. AFL contains operators for performing both data definition and data manipulation. All queries in this guide are composed of AFL operators.

AQL is a high-level declarative language for working with SciDB arrays. It is similar to the SQL language for relational databases, but uses an array-based data model and a more comprehensive analytical query set compared with standard relational databases.
The iquery executable is the basic command-line tool for communicating with SciDB. iquery is the default SciDB client used to issue AQL and AFL commands.

section.para: An important part of SciDB database design is selecting which values will be dimensions and which will be attributes. You can get guidance on database design in the Database Design section of the Creating and Removing Arrays chapter in the full documentation.
A few observations to keep in mind when you are defining your arrays:

listitem.para: Joins of arrays are performed along dimensions.
Operators such as slice and subarray use dimensions to quickly select subregions.
Group-by clauses work over dimensions.
Aggregates work over attributes.
Filtering over dimensions is faster than filtering over attributes.

section.title: Tasks
section.para: To get acquainted with SciDB, you will perform the following tasks.

listitem.para: Create a simple array and retrieve some information about the array.
Load data into an array. There are several ways to do this. We describe a few of them.
Examine ways to select sub-regions from an array.
Walk through an advanced example that combines several operators into a single query.

section.title: Creating an Array

note.para: Note: In this guide, the output of queries is formatted to fit the page nicely. When you run your queries, the output will be the same—but the format of the output will be different. SciDB offers many formatting options. One useful one is the dcsv format, illustrated below.

section.para: The basic way to create an array in SciDB is to use the CREATE ARRAY statement.

step.para: From a command prompt, start iquery with AFL as the language.$ iquery -a Optionally, you can start iquery with the dcsv format option: this will display output one cell per line, with some other useful information.$ iquery -o dcsv -a Either command opens an AFL command prompt.AFL%

Use the CREATE ARRAY statement to create an array.--afl CREATE ARRAY test <val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0]; --show-output=noThis creates a 5x5 array, with a single, double precision floating-point attribute. Note the following about the CREATE ARRAY statement:
The first argument in the name for the array, in this case test.
The next argument is the attribute list, contained within '<>'. Here we have only a single attribute, so we specify its name and data type.
The third argument is the dimension list, contained within '[]'.
For each dimension, we specify its name, lower bound, upper bound, chunk size, and chunk overlap.
The first dimension is i, starting at 0 and ranging to 4, setting the dimension size to 5. The chunk size for both dimensions is set to 6. In this guide, we always use 0 for the value of the chunk overlap. For details about chunk overlap, see the "Array Dimensions" section of the SciDB User's Guide.
In this case, the second dimension, j, has the same values as the first dimension, but that does not need to be the case.

section.title: Getting Array Information
section.para: After you create an array, you can retrieve information about the array.

listitem.para: List all of the existing arrays.--afl list('arrays'); --output-format=csv --show-output-in-test-file=no
Retrieve the schema for a particular array.--afl show(test); --output-format=dense
Retrieve the contents for a particular array.--afl scan(test); --output-format=denseAs you can see, test is currently empty.

section.title: Populating an Array with Data
section.para: SciDB offers several ways to get data into an array.

para.link: Populate the array with the same value in every cell
Populate the array using an expression
Populate the array from a file

section.title: Constant Values
section.para:
This section describes how to populate an array with a single value. We use the build operator, which takes two arguments:
A schema, which is the list of attributes and dimensions, with their details. Note that for the build operator, you must specify exactly one attribute.
An expression, which specifies the values for the attribute.

listitem.para: Populate an array. The following query fills a 5x5 array with 1's.--afl build(<val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0],1); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yesNote that this query does not store the result anywhere—that is, SciDB does not create a new array filled with 1's.

To store the result of our previous query, we need to use the store operator.--afl store(build(<val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0],1),test); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yesThis stores the output from the build operator into the array, test.

section.title: Calculated Values
section.para: This section describes how to use expressions to populate an array with values.

step.para: SciDB has a random function, random(), that is useful for populating an array with randomly-generated values. Here, we create a 3x4 array, and fill it with random numbers between 10 and 99.--afl store(build(<randomVal:int64>[i=0:2,3,0, j=0:3,4,0],random()%90+10),random_100); --output-format=dense --show-output-in-test-file=no --chunkify=yesNote that in this query, our attribute is of type int64 (an integer data type). Of course, your output will differ, as the random() function produces random output.

This example uses the iif operator—inline if—to populate an array with two different values.--afl store(build(<val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0],iif(i=j,1,0)),test); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yesNote that we have created a 5x5 identity array. The iif operator takes three arguments:
An expression to evaluate. In this case, the expression is i=j.
A value to store into a cell if the expression is true.
A value to store into a cell if the expression is false.
So, in this example, when i=j, we store 1, and in all other cells, we store 0.

You can nest the iif operator to get more control over the values to add.--afl store(build(<val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0],iif(i>j,1,iif(i=1,7,0))),test); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yesIn this example, if i > j, we add a 1 to the array, and if i <= j, SciDB evaluates the nested iif function, and adds a 7 or 0 to the array, depending on whether the second expression is true.

section.title: Load from a File
section.para: In many cases, your data exists in a file on disk. Here we describe how to load from a CSV-formatted file into a SciDB array. There are several other approaches to loading data from disk files, and they are discussed in the SciDB User's Guide.
Suppose that you have a CSV file, /tmp/datafile.csv, with the following content:Type,MPG Truck, 23.5 Sedan, 48.7 SUV, 19.6 Convertible, 26.8
We will use the SciDB utility, csv2scidb, to convert this file into the SciDB format, and then load it into an array.

step.para: Create a SciDB array to hold the data.--afl create array A <type:string, mpg:double> [x=0:*,10,0]; --show-output=no

Convert the data into the SciDB format. Note that you run csv2scidb from your Linux terminal prompt, not from inside an iquery session.$ csv2scidb -p SN -s 1 < /tmp/datafile.csv > /tmp/datafile.scidbThe details of the csv2scidb utility are described in the SciDB User's Guide.

Now load the SciDB-formatted file into your array. For the load query, you need to specify the full system path name for the file that you are loading.AFL% load(A, '/tmp/datafile.scidb');{x} type,mpg {0} "Truck",23.5 {1} "Sedan",48.7 {2} "SUV",19.6 {3} "Convertible",26.8

section.title: Selecting Subsets of an Array
section.para: One common task is selecting subsets of an array. SciDB allows you to reduce matrices to contiguous or noncontiguous subsets of its cells.
Let's look at a single array to compare the three SciDB reduction operators, subarray, slice, and thin.

step.para: We will use the array that we created earlier, test, and fill it with values.--afl store(build(<val:double>[i=0:4,6,0, j=0:4,6,0], i*5 +j+1),test); --show-output=no
Select a 3x3 sub array from the interior of the array:--afl subarray(test,1,1,3,3); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes
Slice the third column (j=2), and then the second row (i=1): --afl slice(test,j,2); --output-format=dense--afl slice(test,i,1); --output-format=dense

Use the thin operator to uniformly sample data from the array. --afl thin(test,0,2,0,2); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yes--afl thin(test,1,3,1,2); --output-format=dense --chunkify=yesThe thin operator selects elements from given array dimensions at defined intervals.

section.title: The Power of Operator Composition
section.para: You can use combinations of operations on SciDB data. This allows you to view and analyze data in a nearly endless variety of ways.
For example, let's look at a query to list the SciDB functions:--afl list('functions'); --show-output=no

If you run this query, it returns several hundred elements. Here are the first few items:{No} name,profile,deterministic,library {0} "%","double %(double,double)",true,"scidb" {1} "%","int16 %(int16,int16)",true,"scidb" {2} "%","int32 %(int32,int32)",true,"scidb" {3} "%","int64 %(int64,int64)",true,"scidb" {4} "%","int8 %(int8,int8)",true,"scidb" {5} "%","uint16 %(uint16,uint16)",true,"scidb" {6} "%","uint32 %(uint32,uint32)",true,"scidb" {7} "%","uint64 %(uint64,uint64)",true,"scidb" {8} "%","uint8 %(uint8,uint8)",true,"scidb" Note that the remainder function, %, is overloaded—it can be used on most of the numeric data types. Several of the other SciDB functions are also overloaded.
Now let's say that you want only the names of functions, and you want them sorted, and you only want one record per function name. One way to do this is as follows:

step.para:
Run the following query to create an array:--afl store(sort(project(filter(list('functions'), library='scidb'),name)),functionsArray); --show-output=no Let's break down the actions in this query:
Starting from the inside—which is where the SciDB engine starts—we have list('functions'), which lists information about all functions.
We filter the list of functions to return only the ones in SciDB itself (not in any add-on libraries).
Next, we project only the name of the functions—this is similar to SELECT name from SQL.
We then sort the list and store it to a SciDB array.
Let's take a look at the schema of functionsArray:--afl show(functionsArray); --output-format=dense

We will use redimension_store to convert the attribute, name, to a dimension which removes duplicate values. First, we need to create a target array that has a string dimension to match the string attribute, name. And since all arrays need at least one attribute, we the count function to create an attribute that counts the number of occurrences of each function name.--afl create array target <count:uint64 null> [name(string)=*,1000,0]; --show-output=no

And finally, we redimension the source array into the target.--afl redimension_store(functionsArray, target, count(*) as count); --output-format=dcsvAs you can see, the dimension actually contains the names of the SciDB functions. The attribute, count, contains the number of variations of the corresponding function.
